content.description:
Other than the thorn bush at the start of the route, this route is pretty neat. It has good hand/fist jams. A bouldery start (the crux) gets you into the crack, which starts with thin hands but widens to fists. The crack then constricts again and then widens up again to offwidth size (although no offwidth moves were required).

Like the other routes at Birds and Bees, this route could use some more brushing/cleaning.
content.protection: We were able to set up a toprope anchor on the tree above the route; however, one should take care to extend the anchor over/past the chimney to avoid undue wear on the rope, as it will run over multiple dull edges. It would protect decently for a trad lead, although larger pieces (#5/6 Camalot) would be nice for the easier upper half of the route.
content.location: The route is in the upper part of Birds and Bees, on the east side of the gully that seperates the two halfs of Upper Birds and Bees. Look for a somewhat obvious crack just east of a group of trees as you bushwhack up the gully. The route is immediately west of a short but large chimney.

climbs.name: Unnamed
climbs.fa: Ben Mason, Paul R, John Wester, 3/10/18

content.description:
This is a nice, slabby climb with a cool move in the middle. Start as for

Short & Sweet

, but move slightly left after the dihedral ends, and then stay slightly right of the black streak that runs up the rock.
content.protection:
We toproped this using the anchor for

Short & Sweet

.
content.location:
This route is left of

Short & Sweet

on the west half of Upper Birds and Bees.

content.description:
This is a fun, little, chimney climb to do if you're already at the crag. Combine this with ?Don't Stop When You're Tired? for a bit more climbing to get the most out of your day. It can probably be led on gear, but you would likely catch yourself in the event of a fall before your gear would have the chance to due to the narrow nature of the chimney. It would make a decent solo for a more fun way to set up a toprope anchor for

Used Protection

. Oh and of course an awkward thorny bush right at the bottom adds character.
content.protection: This can probably be lead on gear, but you would probably catch yourself in the event of a fall. A TR anchor can be made by slinging the tree and backed up with a few small to medium cams.
content.location:
This ascends the large, obvious chimney below the large tree at Birds and the Bees. It is directly above

Don't Stop When You're Tired

and directly to the right of

Used Protection

.

climbs.name: Short & Sweet
climbs.fa: Paul R, Ben Mason, John Wester

content.description:
Short & Sweet is a fun, moderate, slabby climb. Start to the right of a ~15 feet right-facing dihedral. Climb up big crimps and good holds with good feet directly under the tree/shrub.

We pulled off a couple basketball-sized rocks from the top, and there is more loose rock above and in the very upper sections. Be careful!
content.protection: We built a toprope anchor using the tree at the top, backed up with a 1# Camalot about 3-4 feet further behind the tree. This route could be led on smaller gear, though it is short and would be runout to the point of a possible groundfall early in the route.
content.location: This route is in Upper Birds and Bees. The route is on the west side of the gully/wash that splits Upper Birds and Bees in half.

content.description:
This is a fun crack climb. It is a little dirty and still could use some brushing. We pulled some large pieces off during the FA.

Climb the crack, go right when the crack thins, then cut back left after the jug to place more gear. Once it mellows out, move right to a horizontal crack to build an anchor. Clean the route, climb up some 4th Class, then walk up and around to the left of the climb.
content.location: It is on the left side of the crag on the face parallel to the Urban Alpine Crag. Belay on a ledge.

content.description:
The 'crux' is pulling the first bulge. There is great pro at head height.

Walk off, or bring a cordelette to sling a monolithic boulder up top.

It was named after my friend's son who was born the same day.
content.location:
Hike until you feel like you can't get any higher, and you will run into this climb. Follow the weakness, just left of '

Unnamed

" and "

Short and Sweet

".

content.description:
You bushwhacked all the way over from Urban Alpine and didn't expect the hike to be so long? The hill is much taller than it looked, but the rockface is shorter than expected? This is probably not worth the hike up, but if you combine this route with the chimney

Stop When You're Finished

to milk the most climbing we could after hiking up. It can be led, but it can also be TR'd without setting up a new TR anchor from

Used Protection

so you can get another quick route in by shifting the master point over a few feet.
content.protection:
For a TR anchor, sling the large tree above

Stop When You're Finished

, and back it up with a few cams. This would protect well with small to medium cams or a few nuts.
content.location:
This is located at Birds and The Bees right below the belay ledge for

Stop When You're Finished

.

content.description: This route goes up the center of a 5 foot roof. Currently there is a beehive just the left of the 3rd bolt which has a permdraw on it currently. The grade is an estimate. Let me know if you have any information on this route.
content.location: This line goes up the large roof on the right side of the crag.

content.description: I spent a lot of time cleaning out these cracks after losing my first climbing friend. I'm sure I'm probably not the real first ascentionist, but I just wanted to listed these routes for my friend.
content.location: Keep going up!!! This is located on the far northeast side of the hill. Keep following the trail/cairns up through the screefields and under the big roof, pass the newly bolted sport routes on the left, and continue trending up and right traversing over ridges till you come to the offwidth splitter start.
